text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Tuesday.
- U.N. administrator of Eastern Slavonia Jacques Klein hands over to local Serbs a list of 150 suspected war criminals put together by the Croatian government.
- INA oil company leaves behind in Albania several million dollars worth of equipment. Will the armed guards be able to protect it?
- Jacques Klein: The way Tudjman sees it, the Serbs are guaranteed their safety in the Croatian Danube region and thus can remain in the area.
- Economy minister Davor Stern expects foreign investment to double in 1997 from $280 million it totalled in 1996.
- Schools in Eastern Slavonia to coordinate their work with the rest of the country in autumn.
- State statistics bureau estimates the 1996 gross domestic product (GDP) at $18.8 billion although the final figure will be available in a month, says its head Ivan Rusan.
- Small businesses to be loaned 20 million marks through new Zagrebacka Banka credit lines.

- Austrian investor INB interested in buying a 51-percent stake in Dubrovnik's war-damaged hotel Belvedere, which would also require a 39 million mark investment into its rebuilding. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
